exit: The <tt>exit</tt> statement has the following syntax:
exit simply ends the execution of the current script function, method, or event. Note there is a slight difference in use here depending on the scope:
if you use <tt>exit</tt> in a script function or method it will simply exit the function and return to the code that called the function
if you use exit in a code block from within an object, it will exit the entire event even if there are various separate code blocks after exit has been called.

When used in an event, <tt>exit</tt> is typically used to avoid an instance running any further code when a specific condition has been met (or not). The code below outlines an example of how it would be used, in this case within a Collision Event, although it can be used in any event.

{ANY_CODE} if (!visible)
{nbsp_x4}{
{nbsp_x4}exit;
{nbsp_x4}}
while (place_meeting(x, y))
{nbsp_x4}{
{nbsp_x4}x -= lengthdir_x(1, direction - 180);
{nbsp_x4}y -= lengthdir_y(1, direction - 180);
{nbsp_x4}}
The above code checks a variable and if it resolves to <tt>true</tt>, then it exits the code block, otherwise it goes ahead and runs the rest of the code.
NOTE: It does not end the execution of the game. For that you need to use the function game_end().
